title: Welcome to Haiyang‚Äôs Tech Portfolio
text:
Hello! I‚Äôm Xu Haiyang, a Computer Science graduate specializing in Cybersecurity & Cyber-Physical Systems. This website serves as a portfolio to showcase my projects, research, and technical knowledge in IoT, Cybersecurity, AWS Cloud, and AI.



Education:

Singapore Management University (Aug 2021 ‚Äì Dec 2024) - BSc in Computer Science (Cybersecurity & CPS)
Singapore Polytechnic (Mar 2018 ‚Äì Apr 2021) - Diploma in Computer Engineering

Certifications: AWS Certified Solutions Architect
Programming Skills: JavaScript, R Coding, Python, ReactJS, Java, C/C++
Cybersecurity Skills: OWASP ZAP, SQL Injection Testing, IAM, Risk Management, Threat Intelligence




This website is structured into several sections to help visitors and myself find useful solutions:
- Cyber Defense & Threat Intelligence: Articles and resources on security best practices, penetration testing, and risk management.
- Mastering Code & Development: Code snippets, tutorials, and solutions for common programming challenges.
- Cloud Computing & Scalability: Insights into AWS, serverless computing, and cloud security.
- GitHub Mastery & DevOps: Guides on version control, GitHub Actions, and repository management.
- AI & Machine Learning Innovations: Machine learning, deep learning, and AI-related projects.




AWS Security Automation (View Project) - Implemented AWS Lambda, API Gateway, and Security Hub for real-time security analysis.
Insider Threat Detection (View Project) - Built ML-based risk assessment using TensorFlow and Scikit Learn.
IoT Smart System (View Project) - Designed IoT applications with AWS cloud connectivity.





Deep Learning Week Hackathon (2022) - Led AI solution for real-time pedestrian and vehicle detection.
Lyve Cloud Hackathon (2022) - Developed cloud-based media streaming server.




Feel free to connect with me on:
- üìß Email: haiyang.xu.2021@scis.smu.edu.sg
- üîó LinkedIn
- üêô GitHub
- üìÑ Download My Resume


In the AI era, cybersecurity professionals are the guardians of innovation, ensuring that technological advancements remain secure and trustworthy.

title: 20 Useful ChatGPT Commands for Research & Productivity
text:
Below is a list of 20 commands (prompt techniques) you can use with ChatGPT to improve your research and work productivity. Each command includes a brief explanation and a copyable prompt.


Prompt:
Summarize the following text: [insert text]  
Explanation: Quickly distills lengthy articles or reports into a concise summary.



Prompt:
Explain [concept] like I‚Äôm 5.  
Explanation: Breaks down complex topics into simple, easy-to-understand language.



Prompt:
Act as a [research assistant/expert in renewable energy/etc.].  
Explanation: Guides ChatGPT to respond in the tone and style of a specified expert.



Prompt:
Generate an outline for a report on [topic].  
Explanation: Creates a structured blueprint for projects, articles, or presentations.



Prompt:
List the pros and cons of [subject].  
Explanation: Helps evaluate options by comparing benefits and drawbacks.



Prompt:
Compare [option A] and [option B].  
Explanation: Provides a side-by-side comparison for decision-making.



Prompt:
Translate the following text to [language]: [insert text].  
Explanation: Converts text into different languages, aiding localization.



Prompt:
Rewrite this text in simpler language: [insert text].  
Explanation: Makes technical or dense content more accessible.



Prompt:
Brainstorm creative ideas for [project/topic].  
Explanation: Generates innovative ideas to overcome creative blocks.



Prompt:
Give me a step-by-step guide on how to [task].  
Explanation: Breaks down tasks into clear, actionable steps.



Prompt:
Give me synonyms for [word].  
Explanation: Helps find alternative words for better phrasing.



Prompt:
Explain this code: [insert code].  
Explanation: Breaks down and explains code snippets in simple terms.



Prompt:
Find and fix errors in this code: [insert code].  
Explanation: Identifies and corrects errors in programming code.



Prompt:
Generate a sample paragraph about [topic].  
Explanation: Creates placeholder or draft text for various needs.



Prompt:
Create a study plan for learning [subject] in [timeframe].  
Explanation: Helps organize study schedules effectively.



Prompt:
Extract the key points from this text: [insert text].  
Explanation: Pulls out essential details from dense information.



Prompt:
Create a to-do list for [goal/project].  
Explanation: Structures tasks efficiently for productivity.



Prompt:
Convert this text to bullet points: [insert text].  
Explanation: Reformats text into easier-to-read structures.



Prompt:
Summarize the major events of [historical period].  
Explanation: Provides concise historical overviews.



Prompt:
Write a professional email for [purpose].  
Explanation: Creates well-structured emails for professional use.

title: Useful GitHub Commands
text:
git clone <repository_url>
Explanation: This command creates a local copy of the remote repository. Replace <repository_url> with the actual URL of the repository you want to clone (e.g., https://github.com/user/repo.git).



git status
Explanation: This command shows the current status of your working directory and staging area, including changes that are staged for commit and those that are not.



git add <file_or_directory>
Explanation: This command stages changes for the next commit. Replace <file_or_directory> with the file or directory you want to stage. To stage all changes, use git add ..



git commit -m "Your commit message"
Explanation: This command commits the staged changes to the repository with a message describing the changes. Replace "Your commit message" with a brief but descriptive message.



git log
Explanation: This command shows the commit history, listing all commits made in the repository, along with their details such as author, date, and commit message.



git push origin <branch_name>
Explanation: This command uploads your local commits to the remote repository. Replace <branch_name> with the branch you‚Äôre working on (e.g., main or develop).



git pull origin <branch_name>
Explanation: This command fetches and merges changes from the remote repository into your local repository. Replace <branch_name> with the name of the branch you want to pull from (usually main).



git checkout -b <new_branch_name>
Explanation: This command creates and switches to a new branch. Replace <new_branch_name> with the name you want for the new branch.



git checkout <branch_name>
Explanation: This command switches to an existing branch. Replace <branch_name> with the name of the branch you want to switch to.



git merge <branch_name>
Explanation: This command merges changes from another branch into your current branch. Replace <branch_name> with the branch you want to merge.



git branch -d <branch_name>
Explanation: This command deletes a local branch. Replace <branch_name> with the name of the branch you want to delete.



git remote -v
Explanation: This command shows the URLs of the remote repositories associated with your local repository.



git remote add origin <repository_url>
Explanation: This command adds a remote repository to your local repository. Replace <repository_url> with the actual URL of the remote repository.



git reset --hard
Explanation: This command resets your working directory and staging area to the last commit, discarding any uncommitted changes.



git diff
Explanation: This command shows the differences between the working directory and the staging area, or between two commits.



git stash
Explanation: This command temporarily saves your changes, allowing you to work on something else without committing those changes.



git tag <tag_name>
Explanation: This command creates a tag for a specific commit. Replace <tag_name> with the name of the tag (e.g., v1.0).



git push origin <tag_name>
Explanation: This command pushes the tag to the remote repository.



git push origin --delete <branch_name>
Explanation: This command deletes a branch from the remote repository.



gh issue list
Explanation: This command lists open issues in a GitHub repository (requires the GitHub CLI). You can filter, view, and manage issues directly from the terminal.



gh issue create
Explanation: This command creates a new GitHub issue (requires the GitHub CLI). Follow the prompts to enter the issue title, description, and labels.
